snippet: New York City is facing up to the threats posed by rising seas and flooding in the subway system during severe storms, but the city is years away from — and billions of dollars short of — armoring itself.
abstract: New York City, with a 520-mile-long coast lined largely by teeming roads and fragile infrastructure, is gingerly facing up to the intertwined threats posed by rising seas and ever-more-severe storm flooding; critics say the Bloomberg administration is moving too slowly to address the potential for flooding that could paralyze transportation, cripple the low-lying financial district and temporarily drive hundreds of thousands of people from their homes.
lead_paragraph: New York City is facing up to the threats posed by rising seas and flooding in the subway system during severe storms, but the city is years away from — and billions of dollars short of — armoring itself.

headline.seo: New York Faces Rising Seas and Slow City Action
headline.main: New York Is Lagging as Seas and Risks Rise, Critics Warn
headline.print_headline: New York Is Lagging as Seas And Risks Rise, Critics Warn

keywords.value: Office of Long-Term Planning and Sustainability (NYC)
